Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Move package commit logic to IPackageUploadService" (#4764) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Right now, `ApiController` and `PackagesController` both have the logic where we reliably write to `packages` container and to the database whilst still handling failures. This logic is duplicated.

I have moved this logic to `IPackageUploadService.CommitPackageAsync`. Right now, this is just a refactoring but the goal in a subsequent PR is to write (and delete in failure cases) packages to the `validating` container if the package has `PackageStatus.Validating`. Otherwise, existing behavior is maintained.

Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4646.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add APIs to upload, download, and delete a package from the validation container" (#4761) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Depends on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/4759.

This introduces a new private container which is a sibling to the existing `packages` container. The file name pattern is the same as the packages container. The reason I did this is that currently we are using the file storage service to synchronously (with respect to push) reject cases where `{id}.{version}.nupkg` collides with another package. If a package is pushed into the `validation` container, we should still detect this case synchronously instead of having the collision occur asychronously and beyond the user's control. When we move `packages` to a better format, then we can do the same with `validation`.

These APIs will be called by gallery (save) and orchestrator (download and delete).

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Split some of PackageFileService and FileStorageService into NuGetGallery.Core" (#4759) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Orchestrator needs to upload to the packages container when a package becomes available. Therefore, I had to split `IPackageFileService` into two, introducing a new `ICorePackageFileService`. Ideally I would have moved the whole service down to `NuGetGallery.Core` but there were some web service specific methods on `IPackageFileService` that don't make sense for orchestrator (e.g. `CreateDownloadPackageActionResultAsync` which requires an MVC dependency).

`IFileStorageService` has some constants which relate to all sorts of container names and content types not specific to the `packages` container. Instead of splitting these methods in half, I chose to just push the entire methods and their associated constants down to `NuGetGallery.Core` instead of having to do `override` in `NuGetGallery`. I think this is the right move since it is simpler and more likely than not we'll have to push more into `NuGetGallery.Core` as time goes on.

By extension, `IFileStorageService` also had to be split up because it also has an MVC-dependent method, thus introducing `ICoreFileStorageService`.

Finally, I split the test classes up so that implementations now in `NuGetGallery.Core` are tested by `NuGetGallery.Core.Facts`.

In general I like this pattern since we have less and less logic in our web app and more and more logic in a project which is agnostic of entry point and is abstracted away from view concerns (like .cshtml or HTTP redirects).

Depends on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/4759.

This introduces a new private container which is a sibling to the existing `packages` container. The file name pattern is the same as the packages container. The reason I did this is that currently we are using the file storage service to synchronously (with respect to push) reject cases where `{id}.{version}.nupkg` collides with another package. These APIs will be called by gallery (save) and orchestrator (download and delete).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[api] [nuget.org] api/v2/FindPackagesById()/$count endpoint is broken" (#4760) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @evil-shrike on September 27, 2017 13:12_

Previously url `api/v2/FindPackagesById()/$count` worked - for example:
https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/FindPackagesById()/$count?includePrerelease=false&$top=160&id=%27Rx-Linq%27&includeAllVersions=false
Now it returns 404 Not Found.
I couldn't find any announcements about such API breaking changes. 
We use Artifactory extensively as out internal nuget server, it also is used as proxy for nuget.org (for CI builds). Now we're getting errors.

_Copied from original issue: NuGet/Home#5947_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet pack on a simple UAP project fails with MSB4019" (#5949) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Sample: 
[TestProject.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1338998/TestProject.zip)

## Tools
dotnet.exe: v1.1.0
VS: v15.3.5
OS: Win10 Anniversary update

**Works with NuGet version 3.5.0** (`nuget pack TestProject.csproj`)
## Repro:

1. Create a simple UAP class library:
```XML
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Project ToolsVersion="15.0" DefaultTargets="Build" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
  <Import Project="$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\$(MSBuildToolsVersion)\Microsoft.Common.props" Condition="Exists('$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\$(MSBuildToolsVersion)\Microsoft.Common.props')" />
  <PropertyGroup>
    <Configuration Condition=" '$(Configuration)' == '' ">Debug</Configuration>
    <Platform Condition=" '$(Platform)' == '' ">AnyCPU</Platform>
    <ProjectGuid>{f58fcc76-7339-4ea0-8569-3f2676107be7}</ProjectGuid>
    <OutputType>Library</OutputType>
    <AppDesignerFolder>Properties</AppDesignerFolder>
    <RootNamespace>TestProject</RootNamespace>
    <AssemblyName>TestProject</AssemblyName>
    <DefaultLanguage>en-US</DefaultLanguage>
    <TargetPlatformIdentifier>UAP</TargetPlatformIdentifier>
    <TargetPlatformVersion Condition=" '$(TargetPlatformVersion)' == '' ">10.0.14393.0</TargetPlatformVersion>
    <TargetPlatformMinVersion>10.0.14393.0</TargetPlatformMinVersion>
    <MinimumVisualStudioVersion>14</MinimumVisualStudioVersion>
    <FileAlignment>512</FileAlignment>
    <ProjectTypeGuids>{A5A43C5B-DE2A-4C0C-9213-0A381AF9435A};{FAE04EC0-301F-11D3-BF4B-00C04F79EFBC}</ProjectTypeGuids>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(Configuration)|$(Platform)' == 'Debug|AnyCPU' ">
    <PlatformTarget>AnyCPU</PlatformTarget>
    <DebugSymbols>true</DebugSymbols>
    <DebugType>full</DebugType>
    <Optimize>false</Optimize>
    <OutputPath>bin\Debug\</OutputPath>
    <DefineConstants>DEBUG;TRACE;NETFX_CORE;WINDOWS_UWP</DefineConstants>
    <ErrorReport>prompt</ErrorReport>
    <WarningLevel>4</WarningLevel>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(Configuration)|$(Platform)' == 'Release|AnyCPU' ">
    <PlatformTarget>AnyCPU</PlatformTarget>
    <DebugType>pdbonly</DebugType>
    <Optimize>true</Optimize>
    <OutputPath>bin\Release\</OutputPath>
    <DefineConstants>TRACE;NETFX_CORE;WINDOWS_UWP</DefineConstants>
    <ErrorReport>prompt</ErrorReport>
    <WarningLevel>4</WarningLevel>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <None Include="project.json" />
  </ItemGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <Compile Include="Class1.cs" />
    <Compile Include="Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs" />
    <EmbeddedResource Include="Properties\TestProject.rd.xml" />
  </ItemGroup>
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(VisualStudioVersion)' == '' or '$(VisualStudioVersion)' < '14.0' ">
    <VisualStudioVersion>14.0</VisualStudioVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <Import Project="$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\Microsoft\WindowsXaml\v$(VisualStudioVersion)\Microsoft.Windows.UI.Xaml.CSharp.targets" />
</Project>
```

2. Try to pack:

```
dotnet pack TestProject.csproj
```

3. It fails with this log:
```
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 15.3.409.57025 for .NET Core
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

<file-path>\TestProject\TestProject.csproj(119,3): error MSB4019: The imported project "C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Microsoft\WindowsXaml\v14.0\Microsoft.Windows.UI.Xaml.CSharp.targets" was not found. Confirm that the path in the <Import> declaration is correct, and that the file exists on disk.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The dreaded "Could not find file..." Problem just bit me again" (#2836) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I tried to add a package to my solution today, received: 

Severity    Code    Description Project File    Line    Suppression State
Error       Failed to initialize the PowerShell host. If your PowerShell execution policy setting is set to AllSigned, open the Package Manager Console to initialize the host first.           0   

The rest of the day was wasted trying to recover an operational IDE with NuGet. I have tried:

```
Uninstall Nuget
Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted (in Powershell ISE (X86) )
Restart VS2015
Install Nuget
```

However, no matter what I do I still can't run the package manager console, getting the dreaded:

```
Could not find file 'C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\typesv3.ps1xml'.
Could not find file 'C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Event.Format.ps1xml'.
Could not find file 'C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Event.Format.ps1xml'.
```

Can anyone help? By the way, I last successfully added a package in this manner using NuGet about two weeks ago.I am using VS2015 with all available updates on Windows 7.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "nuget.exe should find the config file path based on the original working directory" (#5933) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
Updating to a newer version on NuGet.exe breaks building solution. Errors show that it is looking for nuget.config in project folders when there already is a nuget.config at the solution level. 

Targets _IsProjectRestoreSupported and _GenerateRestoreProjectPathWalk seem to be needed. 

Command: NuGet.exe restore -ConfigFile src\.nuget\nuget.config -PackagesDirectory packages\ src\Project.sln

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe and VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.5.0.4487

VS version (if appropriate): 15.4.0 Preview 3.0 [26919.1.d15rel]

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 v15063 (10.0.15063) 

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 3.4.4.1321

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs
error MSB4057: The target "_GenerateRestoreProjectPathWalk" does not exist in the project.
error MSB4057: The target "_IsProjectRestoreSupported" does not exist in the project.
AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\bpguxuqr.e1t.nugetrestore.targets(476,5): error : File \InnerProject1\src\.nuget\nuget.config' does not exist.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Question: I" (#5946) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Is it possible to get similar output with nuget.exe (outside Visual Studio) for this "Package Manager Console" command:

```powershell
PM> (Get-Project -All | ForEach-Object { Get-Package -ProjectName $_.Name })
```
using nuget.exe command line?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Accessibility] “Blocked by project” versions of SDK “Microsoft.NETCore.App” should be shown in grey instead of black" (#5948) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**VSTS ISSUE:** 484554
**NuGet Version:** NuGet 4.4.0-Dev-4438
**VS Version:** D15PreRel 26823.3006
**OS Version:** Windows 10 RS2_Release 15063.2.170323-1837
 
## Repro Steps:
New a Visual C#->.NET Core->Console App (.NET Core) project.
Open PM UI of this project and go to “Installed” tab.
Select the SDK “Microsoft.NETCore.App” in the left panel.
Click the “Version” drop-down list and check the versions.

## Expected Result:
These “blocked by project” versions should be shown in grey (same with the color of “Uninstall” and “Update” buttons).
 
## Actual Result:
These “blocked by project” versions were shown in black as below screenshot.

![attachfilehandler](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2132567/30941215-3009c9f4-a399-11e7-98fd-e49ac1b21968.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Docs for Install command DependencyVersion and Framework flags" (#5858) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`nuget.exe install` added the following options which should be documented.

* DependencyVersion https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/53ad3962093b16795402fb8b364795c2b3d31d0c/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Commands/InstallCommand.cs#L40
* Framework https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/53ad3962093b16795402fb8b364795c2b3d31d0c/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Commands/InstallCommand.cs#L43

See the help when running these commands for more details.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update NU log code docs" (#5857) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The NU log code doc should be updated for 4.4

* NU1607 has moved to NU1107
* NU1606 has moved to NU1108
* NU1608 has been added

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Restore-errors-and-warnings/_compare/a2fe6b4f2f97ef5929b17a3c7dbddc44449114b3...ecc7b4cd554f633c5f9c288e9ff594b7eb78ea37

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Nuget push fails with timeout for some packages - fixed in netcore CLI 2.0" (#5267) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @rudolfdobias on May 22, 2017 23:16_

Hello, hope this is the right place where to put this issue..:
Have an package (https://www.nuget.org/packages/Firefly.net/1.2.1-alpha1) and it cannot be pushed to the nuget.org by any way from the command line.

## Steps to reproduce

```
dotnet nuget push -k xxx-s https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package ..path to the/Firefly.net.1.2.1-alpha1.nupkg'
```

 - Tried desktop OSX / Ubuntu / Docker on Ubuntu - same behavior.
 - Tried myget, it does not work too.
 - Tried raise the timeout - nope
 - Tried to create new blank project and push it - it works.
 - (The package has about 40kbites)

## Expected  behavior

(package successfuly pushed)

## Actual behavior

```
info : Pushing Firefly.net.1.2.1-alpha1.nupkg to 'https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package'...
info :   PUT https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/
info : An error was encountered when fetching 'PUT https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/'. The request will now be retried.
info : An error occurred while sending the request.
info :   Failure when receiving data from the peer
```

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:

Testing on OSX:
```
.NET Command Line Tools (2.0.0-preview1-005977)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.0.0-preview1-005977
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  414cab8a0b

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.12
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.12-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.0.0-preview1-005977/

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.0-preview1-002111-00
  Build    : 1ff021936263d492539399688f46fd3827169983
```

Testing on ubuntu:

```
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.4)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.0.4
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  af1e6684fd

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  14.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         ubuntu.14.04-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/share/dotnet/sdk/1.0.4
```

Thanks



_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#6666_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Feature: 2 Factor Auth for NuGet.org sign in" (#3) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The feature spec for the feature **2 Factor Auth for NuGet.org sign in** is ready for **review**:

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
| [NuGet/Home/wiki/2-Factor-Auth-for-NuGet.org-sign-in](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/2-Factor-Auth-for-NuGet.org-sign-in) | https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/3252|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Changes to NuGet.org service management, and performance improvements in China" (#2) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
For details and discussions, please refer to the blog:
[Changes to NuGet.org service management, and performance improvements in China](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html)
